document_title: Flat warts: Causes, signs and prevention
subsection_content:
Flat warts are caused by human papilloma virus (HPV), specifically HPV types 3, 10, 28 and 49. These strains are benign, do not pose a risk of cancer and are not the same strain as genital warts. . HPV grows well in hot and humid environments. Once it enters the host's body, the virus begins to thicken the top layer of skin and  forms a flat wart.
HPV virus enters the body through cases such as: scratches on the body, sharing personal items with a person with flat warts, spreading from one part of the body to another, direct contact contact with the patient. In addition, people with weakened immune systems are susceptible to HPV virus.
